description: Borrowed from Middle French fragile, from Latin fragilis, formed on frag-, the root of frangere (“to break”). Cognate  fraction, fracture and doublet of frail.

adjectives.description: fragile (comparative fragiler or more fragile, superlative fragilest or most fragile)

entries.meaning: Easily broken or destroyed, and thus often of subtle or intricate structure.
examples: The chemist synthesizes a fragile molecule.
The UN tries to maintain the fragile peace process in the region.

entries.meaning: (UK) Feeling weak or easily disturbed as a result of illness.

examples: He is a very fragile person and gets easily depressed.
